titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Lisa Fox and Curt Royston Papers
1980-1987
MSS 249
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Ashley Todd, 2011.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-08-17T12:17-0400

did.unittitle: Lisa Fox and Curt Royston Papers

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collections is organized into five series based on format.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at Fales Library and Special Collections

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Curt Royston is best known for his proficiency in a variety of media: painting, sculpture, photography, film, and video, and often in combination. His work has been shown extensively throughout the United States and Europe including a 1987 one-man exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Lisa Fox was a leading dancer with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company from 1976-1980 and has been a choreographer with Lisa Fox Danse for over thirty years. Together Royston and Fox collaborated on a series of multimedia installations, as well as a number of 16mm dance-based films throughout the 1980s, the most popular of which is "In Artificial Light" (1983).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains reviews, photographs, transparencies, posters, video and film related to the multimedia collaborations of Lisa Fox and Curt Royston.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Lisa Fox and Curt Royston Papers; MSS 249; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.
